Posts.Content: My DRE was benign (after each of three psa test results which started at 2.1 in 2006 and 5.9 most recently). No history of prostate cancer in my family - I'm 49, married with two kids.
Posts.Signature: PSA 0.2 9/2006, 4.5 12/2011, 5.9 11/2012 Biopsy - 12 samples - 4/12/2013 Results - 4/25/2013 - 2 cores out of 12 positive, 1 suspicious Gleason 3+4 and 4+3 Recommended Larposcopic Prostatectomy June 2013
Posts.Title: First Prostate Biopsy today

Posts.Content: Thanks for the encouraging words Chuck - sometimes I'm OK with what lies ahead and sometimes I read something negative and I have doubt. Good advice on checking the number of surgeries - which I will do at my appointment next week. I'm not at all afraid of surgery (have had before for something unrelated) - it's more a concern about the quality of life outcome,,the better the surgeon the better the result, right?! Cheers (and glad I found this forum - very necessary for those of us new to this scary game), Brian Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Sadly happy to welcome you as a member of "the club." But the good news is that your PC, as the doctor said, most likely IS still confined to the prostate. This is not the end of your world -- it is merely the beginning of the rest of a very, very long life. Your FULL lifespan. Too bad he doesn't do da Vinci robotic surgery also. I've had robotic surgery, but am not as familiar with laparoscopic except that it is minimally invasive like robotic, but without the robotic features. I'm sure the cure rate is pretty much the same though. These techniques have about the same cure rate as traditional "open" surgery. Has your doctor done several hundred of the laparoscopic ones? Ask him this and also about his positive margin rate. If he doesn't have hundreds of surgeries behind him, you might want to seek a 300+ uro/surgeon who does da Vinci OR open. But, if this doctor is highly qualified, and you are comfortable with him, you should be okay. The skill of the doctor is the most critical thing in avoiding positive margins (when possible) and also in reconstructing the urethra and sparing the erection controlling nerves (when possible). Yup, younger patients do tend to recover faster and more completely (in terms of continence, sexual function, etc), so it sounds like you're on your way to being cured. Remember the key though -- be sure that the surgeon is highly experienced and highly competent. That's number one. Good luck! Chuck
Posts.Signature: PSA 0.2 9/2006, 4.5 12/2011, 5.9 11/2012 Biopsy - 12 samples - 4/12/2013 Results - 4/25/2013 - 2 cores out of 12 positive, 1 suspicious Gleason 3+4 and 4+3 Recommended Larposcopic Prostatectomy June 2013
Posts.Title: First Prostate Biopsy today

Posts.Content: I just had my first biopsy today and it went down much better than I expected - thanks, I'm sure, to concious sedation and a skilled doctor and anesthiologist. I was concious the whole time and there was only slight sensation when they fired the 12 needles into my prostate. Inserting the probe was the worst part but that's right when they started the IV so it soon became tolerable. It was a fast procedure once I was in the ultrasound room - maybe 15 minutes tops although my sense of time was probably affected by the drugs. The best thing is that it didn't really hurt at all afterwards - just a little sore and almost no blood in my urine (actually none after the first void). I dreaded this for so long - I would now say go for it as long as you have concious sedation. Let's face it, no one wants to have this procedure but it was quick, relatively tolerable and it just might save your life...but get the concious sedation to avoid pain (real pain!). Now just waiting for the results in 10 days.

Posts.Title: First Prostate Biopsy today

Posts.Content: Well, got my results last Thursday and no matter that I thought I was prepared, it still stunned me. One core Gleason 4+3, one 3+3 and one PIN. Good news (really?) according to my doc is that it's almost certainly confined to prostate and because of my relative youth (49) I'm a good candidate for complete cure with surgery (ouch) with all that that possibly entails. So I've had a year to prepare for this and I've come to conclusion that it's surgery for me. My urologist specializes in Larposcopic Prostatectomy - yippee! I signed the consent forms on the way out of the office and have been told it will take place in about 6 weeks - but I have another appointment in two weeks so I have time to reflect on my options and come up with additional questions. Any great insight from those who have gone before? Thanks!

Posts.Title: First Prostate Biopsy today

Posts.Content: I'm 49, otherwise healthy male. At 42 my first psa test was 0.2. At 47 on a routine physical my psa was 4.5. DRE was negative. 6 months later my PSA was 5.9, DRE negative. Referred to urologist - recommended biopsy. I had concious sedation - no pain, just some quick initial discomfort. Anticipation was much worse than actual procedure. Cancer found in two cores, 4+3 and 3+4. Surgery scheduled for 8 weeks after biopsy (you don't want surgery too soon after biopsy and it doesn't make any difference in long-term survival rate - READ Dr. Patrick Walsh's - How to survive prostate cancer - I just downloaded on google play for 10 bucks, well worth it!). Doctor says excellent chance that I can be completely cured and as I have a long life ahead of me, surgery is by far the best option. My biopsy SAVED my life - get it done!
Posts.Signature: PSA 0.2 9/2006, 4.5 12/2011, 5.9 11/2012 Biopsy - 12 samples - 4/12/2013 Results - 4/25/2013 - 2 cores out of 12 positive, 1 suspicious Gleason 3+4 and 4+3 Recommended Larposcopic Prostatectomy June 2013

Posts.Title: Do I need a biopsy?

Posts.Content: One week past my prostate removal surgery and I'm feeling amazingly well - certainly much better than at 48 hours out!! Yipee - I'm really recovering nicely and the surgery got all the cancer according to my surgeon. Will get my catheter removed in another week along with final pathology report. Life gets better!
